column1: AutoIT;"AutoIt v3 is a freeware BASIC-like scripting language designed for automating the Windows GUI and general scripting.  It uses a combination of simulated keystrokes
column2: mouse movement and window/control manipulation in order to automate tasks in a way not possible or reliable with other languages (e.g. VBScript and SendKeys).  AutoIt is also very small
column9:
2003 out of the box with no annoying ""runtimes"" required! You can even make compiled executable scripts that can run without AutoIt being installed!";"

What the authors say:

AutoIt was initially designed for PC ""roll out"" situations to reliably configure thousands of PCs
column10:
but with the arrival of v3 it has become a powerful language able to cope with most scripting needs.

AutoIt can:

  • Provide a general-purpose scripting language for all Windows versions
  • Simulate keystrokes (supports most keyboard layouts)
  • Simulate mouse movements and clicks
  • Move
column11:
resize and manipulate windows
  • Interact directly with ""controls"" on a window (set/get text from edit controls
column14:
etc.)
  • Create complex user interfaces (GUIs)
  • Work with the clipboard to cut/paste text items
  • Provide a scriptable RunAs function for Windows 2000/XP/2003

    • Unlike AutoIt2
column15: the new AutoIt v3 language has a much more standard                syntax -similar to VBScript and BASIC - and now supports complex                expressions
column17:
looping and everything else that veteran scripters would expect.

As with previous versions
column18:
AutoIt has been designed to be as small as possible (~115KB) and stand-alone with no external .dll files or registry entries required.  Scripts can also be compiled into stand-alone executables with Aut2Exe.

There will also be updates to the ActiveX and DLL versions of AutoIt called AutoItX - unlike v2 this will be a combined control (COM and standard DLL functions in the same DLL).  AutoItX will allow you to add the unique features of AutoIt to your own favourite scripting or programming languages!

Best of all
column19: AutoIt continues to be FREE - but if you want to support the time
column20:
money and effort spent on the project and web hosting then you may donate using the link to your left in the menu.


OATS Comments:

AutoIt very powerful scripting software - it will allow you to automate a great number of tasks.  For most end users there will probably be easier to use macro programs
column21: (such as AutoHotKey)  however for some people who want the 'ultimate power' in scripting
column22:
this might be appropriate.

column1: CLiCk, Speak;"CLiCk
column3: freely available extension for the Firefox web browser. It is part of the CLC-4-TTS Suite of products
column4: it features a mouse driven interface
column5:
and it reads web pages - hence its name.";"

Unlike Fire Vox which is designed for visually impaired users
column7: Speak is designed for sighted users who want text-to-speech functionality. It doesn't identify elements or announce events - two features that are very important for visually impaired users but very annoying for sighted users. It also has a simplified
column8: mouse driven interface that is designed to be easy for users familiar with point-and-click graphical user interfaces. Like Fire Vox
column12: and Linux; and Fire Vox has multilingual support
column13:
making it great for users who are trying to learn a foreign language and need to hear foreign language web sites read out to them for practice.

If you're a sighted user who wants to have web pages read to you because you have cognitive issues (for example
column15: because you have literacy issues (like me - I can understand spoken Mandarin Chinese just fine
column16: but reading is difficult for me)
column17: because you want to reduce eyestrain and listen to a web page being read
column19: then you are likely to prefer CLiCk
column20:
Speak over Fire Vox.

The Core Library Components for Text-To-Speech (CLC-4-TTS) Suite is a set of extensions for Firefox. It consists of a library for doing text-to-speech synthesis (the Core library)
column21: a library for navigating the HTML DOM (the Utils library)
column22:
and an application that uses the libraries to act as a screen reader (Fire Vox).

While it currently only works on Firefox
column23: it would be possible for me to create versions of this for other Mozilla products such as Thunderbird. I would have to rewrite the application portion
column24: but the libraries would largely remain untouched. These libraries can also be used to construct other extensions that are not necessarily aimed at the visually impaired. Both are directions that I am interested in pursuing in the near future

Click-Catch;"Click-Catch(C) is an autoclicker. It means it simulates mouse clicks with constant intervals of time.";"

Click-Catch(C) available options:

  • You may choose which button to simulate between left/right/middle mouse buttons.
  • You can also set single or double click.
  • There are two ""hot keys"" available. You must enable them in settings. ""hot keys"" are disabled by default.
    Combination of ""control""+""x"" pressed together at once starts clicking
column3: when you cannot use ""hot keys"" to start/stop clicking
column4:
there are two buttons implemented.
To start simulation press ""START"" button or press ""STOP"" to stop it
  • You may also need to change time interval between clicks.
    You can set its value from 10 hours to 100 miliseconds.
    Minimal step is 50 miliseconds.
  • There is a possiblity to save your settings. Settings are stored in Windows Registry File.
    Click-Catch(c) has no instalation procedure (it's only one file after all!)
    so it can not delete its entry after deinstalation (delete).
    It has however an option called ""clear WinRegFile entry"".
    Use it freely
column5:
it is harmless.
  • You can check if there is new version available to download easely. Simply chose Help/Check for update!

column1: Concept Coding Framework (CCF);"Around the world
column3: including difficulties to read or write
column4: may use symbols as an alternative or complement to character based texts. Referencing to
column5:
and exchanging these alternatively coded messages over the Internet is difficult due to the lack of standardised encoding schemes and common practises. The Concept Coding Framework (CCF) is being developed to overcome some of these difficulties.";"

News

3 February 2011 - (Mats Lundälv)

In spite of nothing appearing at this spot for quite some time
column7: currently in the context of the AEGIS project. More to appear here soon after the recent move of the server home of OATS
column8:
as well as for the conceptcoding.org domain. More to come - soon hopefully ...


3 September 2009 - (Mats Lundälv)

The summer has passed and the work towards the first CCF release is slowly progressing. Will we make it during the 3rd quarter of 2009 as envisaged ? Well - surprise - possibly not :-/ It currently looks uncertain whether we will be ready during this month. It will probably be a bit later this autumn.

Bengt Farre's completely re-written new SYMBERED version is getting close to completion
column9:
but still has some way to go.

The good news is that Lars Nordberg is well on the way to transfer our CCF databases from MySQL to the Sun JavaDB (based on Apache Derby) Java database. This will provide another option for providing CCF resources (in addition to the MySQL and RDF resources) in a light weight format that will be easier to deploy
column10:
install and use for those who will like to try working with CCF based applications and services.

We'll keep you updated at this space ..


19 June 2009 - (Mats Lundälv)

A first full release of the updated CCF package is now envisaged during the 3rd quarter of 2009. It will cover a set of concepts covering the authorized Blissymbolics vocabulary of around 4450 Bliss-words. These will be organised in a Base Reference Ontology (BRO) with concepts covered by WordNet
column11: and a Complementary Reference Ontology (CRO) for the rest. The Concept Coded concepts in the Reference Ontologies will be linked to an open ended numbers of so called Assistive Ontologies containing the different supported language representations for the concepts - Bliss being the first target for graphical symbol representations
column12: and English and Swedish being the first natural language lexicons fully supported. The structure is already prepared for supporting a number of other symbolic representations
column14:
and a number of other European languages. More will be added as soon as interest and resources will be around.

In technical terms; the first release will contain a Java based CCF Tool for browsing and managing the CCF resources (WordNet
column16:
Assistive Ontologies and symbol resources). The data will be stored in or retrieved from either a MySQL database or an RDF/XML based resource.

The first practical implementation will be an updated version of the SYMBERED tool for creating symbol supported web content via a CMS module written in PHP working towards the MySQL database. (This will be a complete re-write of the first SYMBERED version based on the Papunet CMS). 

The next practical implementation will be the first prototypes of the envisaged CCF symbol support plugin extension for OpenOffice.org within the AEGIS project - planned for the 4th quarter of 2009.

08 June 2009 - (Mats Lundälv)

In the AEGIS project 1:st international workshop (in Slough at RIM 05 June) Dr. Christian Galinski from Infoterm gave a very interesting and informative presentation on issues concerning ""Standards for content in the field of eInclusion - and beyond"" - with great relevance for the CCF work in particular
column17:
and for the AEGIS and Raising The Floor projects in general. We will have to do some studying about ISO//TC 37 ""Terminology and other language and content resources"" ;-)  I hope the presentations will be on-line soon.

22 February 2009 - (Mats Lundälv)

The  concept coding work has continued in slow pace as follow up work after the Nordic SYMBERED project - which is still ongoing.
It is now brought further in relation to a task within the ongoing European and international AEGIS-project. Concept coding will be employed in building open source components for graphic symbol support - in OpenOffice.org
column18:
as well as in prototype Java based cross-platform AAC applications - for mobile devices and other environments.

03/12/2007 - (Andy Judson)

With my move from the University of Dundee's School of Computing
column19: I thought it time I ported the old CCF website to the OATS portal. With the Bliss Think Tank in July'07 we've been busy hacking more demonstrators. Mats
column20: Bengt and Lars have been busy fine-tuning the SYMBERED system (CCF support for CMS - using PHP
column22: Java). I've been busy working on a .NET infrastructure and building a central CCF ontology in SQLServer. The database I've been working with is now populated with around 9000 concepts (based on the STANDUP project ontology) and around 3000 Bliss symbols (some of which are mapped to concept codes). There is an prototype asp.net website where you can search the ontologies
column24: write ruby annotated bliss messages (then you can copy the source to your own website like I've done below). This webservice could be used as a portal to manage the ccf
column26: for use by other software / web applications
column27:
e.g. FoxySymbols. I hope to get the webservice & database hosted soon.

Background

Around the world
column29: including difficulties to read or write
column30: may use symbols as an alternative or complement to character based texts. Referencing to
column31: and exchanging these alternatively coded messages over the Internet is difficult due to the lack of standardised encoding schemes and common practises. This site is intended to motivate
column32: describe and promote the introduction and adoption of a common
column33:
open and vendor neutral Concept Coding Framework (CCF) to overcome some of these difficulties. In particular will act as a base for all contribution to this work - be it formal documentation or informal discussions.

The suggested CCF has been carefully designed to be conformant to the standard language technologies that are rapidly developing and penetrating the Internet communities. In this way we believe that the proposed CCF can contribute to a major leap in bridging between different technologies and products developed for AAC users and
column35:
between these Assistive Technologies (AT) and the main-stream technologies of today's and tomorrow's networked information society.

The bridging approach also implies that the CCF is not intended to replace and exclude the use and development of current and future proprietary assistive technologies in the AAC field. Instead the CCF and its bridging technology and tools are designed to provide added value for all stake-holders; AAC users
column36: special product developers and service providers
column37:
as well as general service and information providers who want to support improved accessibility to their products.

Designed to be used over the Internet for email
column39: chat and/or other emerging Internet based services
column42: be used by software manufacturers also to provide additional functionality
column45:
software and systems with multi-modal language features mainly intended for local use.

Although
column46: this work is part of the EU funded WWAAC project
column47:
the concept coding work is to be kept open source as we want to collaborate with experts and stakeholders in both the AAC field and internet technologies/accessibility area. Thus we are wanting to use this area to establish an interest group in the concept coding approach. if you are interested in getting involved at whatever level then please contact us.

Dasher;"Dasher is an information-efficient text-entry interface
column2:
driven by natural continuous pointing gestures.";"

From the authors:

Dasher is a zooming interface. You point where you want to go
column3: and the display zooms in wherever you point. The world into which you are zooming is painted with letters
column4: so that any point you zoom in on corresponds to a piece of text. The more you zoom in
column5:
the longer the piece of text you have written. You choose what you write by choosing where to zoom.

To make the interface efficient
column6: we use the predictions of a language model to determine how much of the world is devoted to each piece of text. Probable pieces of text are given more space
column7: so they are quick and easy to select. Improbable pieces of text (for example
column8: text with spelling mistakes) are given less space
column9: so they are harder to write. The language model learns all the time: if you use a novel word once
column10:
it is easier to write next time.


A big advantage of Dasher over other predictive text-entry interfaces that offer word-completions to the user is that it is mode-free: the user does not need to switch from a writing mode to an ""accept-model-predictions"" mode.

Another advantage is that it is easy to train the model on any writing style: simply load up an example file
column11:
then write away!


OATS Comment:

Dasher is an amazing innovation on on-screen keyboards - although at first it might seem difficult
column12:
stick with it and you will be astounded at how efficient it is.  Although mainly aimed at users who can use a mouse (or similar device) the Dasher team are working on a switch accessible version.  There is also a version that works well with speech recognition software - Speech Dasher.

See Dasher in action:

David MacKay demonstrated Dasher at the Bett 2006 Special Needs Fringe and you can watch the video created by Leon Cych.Dasher 4.9.0 is now available for download from:

 

  http://download.gnome.org/sources/dasher/4.9/

 

Windows binaries will shortly be available from:

 

 http://www.dasher.org.uk/Download.html

 

Dasher is a predictive text input system for the GNOME Desktop
column13:
suitable for any situation in which a conventional keyboard cannot be used.

 

This is the first in a new development series
column14: including a large number of improvements from a wide variety of contributors. As always
column15: thanks to all Dasher developers and contributors. Please file any bug reports in the GNOME Bugzilla
column16:
and send any comments and feedback to dasher@mrao.cam.ac.uk

";"help-http://www.inference.phy.cam.ac.uk/dasher/DasherSummary2.html

column6:
or juxtapose them in order to create dialogues between different voices.
3. DSpeech integrates a vocal recognition system that
column8:
allows you to create interactive dialogues with the user.
4. Allows you to configure the voices in an independent way.
5. Thanks to apposite TAGs
column9: it allows you to dynamically change the features of the voices during the playback (speed
column13:
or even to spell them out.
6. Allows you to capture and reproduce the content of the ClipBoard.
7. DSpeech is compatible with all vocal engines (SAPI 4-5 compliant).
8. AI dialog system. Not really useful
column14:
but amusing. It does not work in every language.

E-triloquist
column3: the personal computer augmentative communication aid software formerly known as ""SpeakEasy""
column4: developed as a family project.  Dad had amyotrophic lateral sclerosis  (ALS) and lost his ability to speak in the course of the disease.  Son is  particularly versatile in personal computers.  Our first version (named ""SpeakEasy"" at the time) was made available on the Internet in early 1995.  We are now on Version 5.7 with even more new features suggested by current users of the program

AAC Keys is a keyboard and mouse emulation program for Microsoft Windows-based and Macintosh computers.

AAC Keys receives commands through your computer's serial port and translates them into keystrokes and mouse moves
column4:
giving you full control of your computer from another device. AAC Keys implements the common GIDEI (General Input Device Emulating Interface) commands (see below).

AAC Keys has been designed to work with Windows 95
column8:

It does still require that you have already installed RealPlayer from Real. The copyright of the BBC recordings is unchanged: you are simply accessing them through a more accessible presentation of their own website. ACollab is available as a work groups addon for ATutor 1.4+
column8: and as a standalone collaborative work environment that will run on its own. ACollab is ideal for groups working at a distance developing documentation
column11: and ideal for online educators who wish to add group learning activities to their ATutor courses. A demo and download are available if you want to learn more. Or

read on for a list of ACollab features.

ACollab Features:

  • Document Drafting Room: Group members can work within a Web-based document versioning system
column13:
collaborating on document development and publication. Documents developed in the Drafting Room can be transferred to the Shared Documents Library once finalized.

column16:
can retrieve those documents for viewing or downloading.
  • Events Calendar: Events can be posted to the calendar by all group members
column20:
or other group related happenings.

column22:
can post news to be presented to users when they first login to a group.
  • Group Membership Index: Group members can view other group members' profiles and contact information.
  • Mail Inbox: Members can communicate with each other privately.
  • AChat-PHP: Accessible synchronous communication is possible between group members
column23:
ideal for online meetings or group socializing.
  • AForum: AForum is an enhanced version for the ATutor forums. Members post message for others to retrieve later. Forums can be set to read only
column24: reply only

or can be hidden from view.
  • Multi-Lingual Interface: Language can be modified by system administrators

or new language packs can be created using the ATutor.ca translation tools.

Section 508 US) so people with disabilities can participate fully in collaborative and administrative activities.

column36:
and manage group members.

and manage all users on a system.

Acomm;"AComm is an accessible Java-based Instant Messaging and Whiteboard tool. It has been designed to allow assistive technology users to participate in synchronous Internet-based communication activities that have traditionally been inaccessible to them.";"


AComm Features

  • User can login to an existing Jabber account or sign up for a new one.
  • Roster provides ""presence"" information for contacts.
  • Users can participate in private or group chat/whiteboard sessions
  • Text chat window and optional whiteboard
  • Participant list on demand.
  • A variety of whiteboard drawing tools are available
  • Peer description allows any participant to describe the drawn objects. Anti-collision feature ensures one describer per object.
  • Accessibility options
    • Option to play sound effect when a new message arrives.
    • Keyboard drawing checkbox
    • Manual refresh checkbox
    • Show only new checkbox
    • Newest message first checkbox
  • Keyboard enabled drawing lets users use some features of the whiteboard without a mouse.
  • Save and open palette feature lets users create and describe pictures beforehand.

Requirements

  • AComm is a Java application and requires that a Java Runtime Environment be installed on system it is running on.

";"help-http://www.oatsoft.org/Software/acomm/help

column1: Agrip;"The of this project aim is to provide access to the mainstream gaming community not by producing specialist ""accessible games"" but by making mainstream games - and their associated extension and development tools - accessible. Downloads include an accessible version of Quake
column2:
the popular PC game.";"

From the Authors:


Over the past two years
column3: AGRIP has developed an accessible version of Quake and QuakeWorld which allows both single and multi-player games
column4: including the collection of online player statistics. In the future we will add immersive 3D audio and level editing facilities - in addition to the gameplay modifications that are currently possible. At each milestone in the project
column5:
we make public releases of our software.

This page explains the history of the project and the technology involved in more detail.

Contents:

  1. About the AGRIP Project
  2. About our Games
  3. The Technology we Use

About the AGRIP Project

Accessible Gaming Rendering Independence Possible (you can see why we shorten it to ""AGRIP""!) was started in May 2003 with the goal of making a mainstream first-person shooter game for the sighted accessible. It was founded by MatthewAtkinson and SabahattinGucukoglu. This section provides all sorts of information about the project. It is split into the following sections:

  • /ProjectRationale - all about what we're doing and why we're doing it.

  • /TheRoadmap - our plans for development - posted here so you can contact us with suggestions on how to improve them.

  • /TheLogo - description and explanation of the logo
column6:
plus an audio version of it.

  • /OnlineShop - information on how to show your support for the project
column7:
by wearing an AGRIP T-Shirt.

If you've got any suggestions for further topics that could be added to this page (or others)
column8:
feel free to either add them in yourself or ContactUs with your suggestions.

About our Games

For more information about the software on offer here
column9:
you can visit the start pages for each game:

  • AccessibleQuake - the original mainstream game made accessible

  • AudioQuake - the next generation Internet AudioGame

The Technology we Use

The world of game technology is a very interesting one. Here are links to some pages on the Wiki that you can use to start exploring and learning about the various bits and pieces fit together:

  • GameStructure

  • GameEngine

  • GameCode

  • QuakeC

  • AudioGame

  • ImplicitAccessibility


";"help-http://www.agrip.org.uk/DevelopmentSection

column1:
Amaya;"Amaya is a complete Open Source accessible web browsing and authoring environment from WC3";"


W3C's Editor/Browser

Amaya is a Web editor
column2:
i.e. a tool used to create and update documents directly on the Web. Browsing features are seamlessly integrated with the editing and remote access features in a uniform environment. This follows the original vision of the Web as a space for collaboration and not just a one-way publishing medium.

Work on Amaya started at W3C in 1996 to showcase Web technologies in a fully-featured Web client. The main motivation for developing Amaya was to provide a framework that can integrate as many W3C technologies as possible. It is used to demonstrate these technologies in action while taking advantage of their combination in a single
column3:
consistent environment.

Amaya started as an HTML + CSS style sheets editor. Since that time it was extended to support XML and an increasing number of XML applications such as the XHTML family
column5:
and SVG. It allows all those vocabularies to be edited simultaneously in compound documents.

Amaya includes a collaborative annotation application based on Resource Description Framework (RDF)
column7:
and XPointer. Visit the Annotea project home page.

Amaya - Open Source

Amaya is an open source software project hosted by W3C. You are invited to contribute in many forms (documentation
column11:
porting to other platforms...).

The Amaya software is written in C and is available for Windows
column12:
Unix platforms and MacOS X.

Amaya Team

The application is jointly developed by W3C and the WAM (Web
column13: Adaptation and Multimedia) project at INRIA. The core team includes: Irène Vatton (Project lead
column20: Accessing the Web

Atutor;"ATutor is an Open Source Web-based Learning Content Management System (LCMS) designed with accessibility and adaptability in mind.";"

ATutor Features

  • Accessibility: ATutor was designed with accessibility as a priority. A wide range of features ensure assistive technology users can participate fully in learner
column3:
and administrative activities.
  • My Courses : Instructors and students can manage the ATutor courses they teach and/or are enrolled in.
  • Adaptive Navigation: Learners can move through ATutor content using global
column5: or sequential navigation tools. Navigation elements can be displayed as text
column8:
and they can be hidden to simplify the environment.
  • Work Groups: When the ACollab add-on is installed on an ATutor system
column9: learners can collaborate with others on course projects
column10: communicate as a group with the forums and chat
column11: share resources using their group library
column12: schedule activities with the events calendar
column13: and work together on project documents through the drafting room. Exercises or assignments can submitted to the group leader
column14:
or course instructor.
  • Feedback: Following an action (such as saving preference settings
column16: feedback is given on the status of the operation. This could be a success message
column18:
or errors to fix.
  • Preference Settings: Learners can control ATutor features and the theme ATutor is presented in.
  • Communication Tools: Learners can communicate with others using ATutor's private mail
column20: the chat rooms
column21: or the ""User's Online"" tool. Threads and messages can be sorted in a variety of ways. Students can communicate with those in other courses through shared forum
column22:
or a community forum. Subscribe to forums or topic threads to have forum messages sent by email.
  • Content Package Viewer: Learners can export content from ATutor as Content Packages that can be viewed offline in the accompanying viewer.
  • Content Tracker: Learners can keep track of the content pages they have visited.
  • Test Manager: Learners can take tests
column24:
and keep track of their scores.
  • Glossary: Words and phrases added to the glossary by the instructor
column25: can be accessed from terms embedded within content pages
column26:
or viewed alphabetically in their entirety using the Glossary tool.
  • Links Database: Each course has a tool for collecting links to course related Web-based information. Both students and instructors can add links. Instructors can also manage them.
  • Course Search: A search engine allows learners to search course content. Search for courses in the course catalogue.
  • TILE Repository Search: Learners can search the TILE learning objects repository for content related to the topics they are studying
column27:
and download content packages for viewing offline. Instructors

AutoHotKey;"An open source macro style program that can re-map the mouse

keyboard and joystick functions as well as automate pretty much anything!";"

From the authors:

AutoHotkey is a free
column3: open-source utility for Windows. With it
column4:
you can:

  • Automate almost anything by sending keystrokes and mouse clicks. You can write a mouse or keyboard macro by hand or use the macro recorder.
  • Create hotkeys for keyboard
column8:
or combination can become a hotkey.
  • Expand abbreviations as you type them. For example
column9:
typing ""btw"" can automatically produce ""by the way"".
  • Create custom data entry forms
column11:
and menu bars. See GUI for details.
  • Remap keys and buttons on your keyboard
column13:
and mouse.
  • Respond to signals from hand-held remote controls via the WinLIRC client script.
  • Run existing AutoIt v2 scripts and enhance them with new capabilities.
  • Convert any script into an EXE file that can be run on computers that don't have AutoHotkey installed.

    • Getting started might be easier than you think. Check out the quick-start tutorial.

    OATS Comments:

    This is a fantastic resource for assistive technology!  It really unleashes the power of your PC and helps set it up to your exact requirements.  It's a bit technical to get into
column14:
but once into it it is easy - there are some great examples too.


More About Hotkeys

AutoHotkey unleashes the full potential of your keyboard
column17: in addition to the typical Control
column20: you can use the Windows key and the Capslock key as modifiers. In fact
column21: you can make any key or mouse button act as a modifier. For these and other capabilities
column22:
see Advanced Hotkeys.

Other Features

  • Change the volume
column24:
and other settings of any soundcard.
  • Make any window transparent
column26:
or alter its shape.
  • Use a joystick or keyboard as a mouse.
  • Monitor your system. For example
column27:
close unwanted windows the moment they appear.
  • Retrieve and change the clipboard's contents
column28:
including file names copied from an Explorer window.
  • Disable or override Windows' own shortcut keys such as Win+E and Win+R.
  • Alleviate RSI with substitutes for Alt-Tab (using keys
column30:
or buttons).
  • Customize the tray icon menu with your own icon
column36:
and popup menus to interact with the user.
  • Perform scripted actions in response to system shutdown or logoff.
  • Detect how long the user has been idle. For example
column37:
run CPU intensive tasks only when the user is away.
  • Automate game actions by detecting images and pixel colors.
  • Read
column39:
and parse text files more easily than in other languages.
  • Perform operation(s) upon a set of files that match a wildcard pattern.
  • Work with the registry and INI files.

column1: AutoIT;"AutoIt v3 is a freeware BASIC-like scripting language designed for automating the Windows GUI and general scripting.  It uses a combination of simulated keystrokes
column2: mouse movement and window/control manipulation in order to automate tasks in a way not possible or reliable with other languages (e.g. VBScript and SendKeys).  AutoIt is also very small
column9:
2003 out of the box with no annoying ""runtimes"" required! You can even make compiled executable scripts that can run without AutoIt being installed!";"

What the authors say:

AutoIt was initially designed for PC ""roll out"" situations to reliably configure thousands of PCs
column10:
but with the arrival of v3 it has become a powerful language able to cope with most scripting needs.

AutoIt can:

  • Provide a general-purpose scripting language for all Windows versions
  • Simulate keystrokes (supports most keyboard layouts)
  • Simulate mouse movements and clicks
  • Move
column11:
resize and manipulate windows
  • Interact directly with ""controls"" on a window (set/get text from edit controls
column14:
etc.)
  • Create complex user interfaces (GUIs)
  • Work with the clipboard to cut/paste text items
  • Provide a scriptable RunAs function for Windows 2000/XP/2003

    • Unlike AutoIt2
column15: the new AutoIt v3 language has a much more standard                syntax -similar to VBScript and BASIC - and now supports complex                expressions
column17:
looping and everything else that veteran scripters would expect.

As with previous versions
column18:
AutoIt has been designed to be as small as possible (~115KB) and stand-alone with no external .dll files or registry entries required.  Scripts can also be compiled into stand-alone executables with Aut2Exe.

There will also be updates to the ActiveX and DLL versions of AutoIt called AutoItX - unlike v2 this will be a combined control (COM and standard DLL functions in the same DLL).  AutoItX will allow you to add the unique features of AutoIt to your own favourite scripting or programming languages!

Best of all
column19: AutoIt continues to be FREE - but if you want to support the time
column20:
money and effort spent on the project and web hosting then you may donate using the link to your left in the menu.


OATS Comments:

AutoIt very powerful scripting software - it will allow you to automate a great number of tasks.  For most end users there will probably be easier to use macro programs
column21: (such as AutoHotKey)  however for some people who want the 'ultimate power' in scripting
column22:
this might be appropriate.

column1: CLiCk, Speak;"CLiCk
column3: freely available extension for the Firefox web browser. It is part of the CLC-4-TTS Suite of products
column4: it features a mouse driven interface
column5:
and it reads web pages - hence its name.";"

Unlike Fire Vox which is designed for visually impaired users
column7: Speak is designed for sighted users who want text-to-speech functionality. It doesn't identify elements or announce events - two features that are very important for visually impaired users but very annoying for sighted users. It also has a simplified
column8: mouse driven interface that is designed to be easy for users familiar with point-and-click graphical user interfaces. Like Fire Vox
column12: and Linux; and Fire Vox has multilingual support
column13:
making it great for users who are trying to learn a foreign language and need to hear foreign language web sites read out to them for practice.

If you're a sighted user who wants to have web pages read to you because you have cognitive issues (for example
column15: because you have literacy issues (like me - I can understand spoken Mandarin Chinese just fine
column16: but reading is difficult for me)
column17: because you want to reduce eyestrain and listen to a web page being read
column19: then you are likely to prefer CLiCk
column20:
Speak over Fire Vox.

The Core Library Components for Text-To-Speech (CLC-4-TTS) Suite is a set of extensions for Firefox. It consists of a library for doing text-to-speech synthesis (the Core library)
column21: a library for navigating the HTML DOM (the Utils library)
column22:
and an application that uses the libraries to act as a screen reader (Fire Vox).

While it currently only works on Firefox
column23: it would be possible for me to create versions of this for other Mozilla products such as Thunderbird. I would have to rewrite the application portion
column24: but the libraries would largely remain untouched. These libraries can also be used to construct other extensions that are not necessarily aimed at the visually impaired. Both are directions that I am interested in pursuing in the near future

Click-Catch;"Click-Catch(C) is an autoclicker. It means it simulates mouse clicks with constant intervals of time.";"

Click-Catch(C) available options:

  • You may choose which button to simulate between left/right/middle mouse buttons.
  • You can also set single or double click.
  • There are two ""hot keys"" available. You must enable them in settings. ""hot keys"" are disabled by default.
    Combination of ""control""+""x"" pressed together at once starts clicking
column3: when you cannot use ""hot keys"" to start/stop clicking
column4:
there are two buttons implemented.
To start simulation press ""START"" button or press ""STOP"" to stop it
  • You may also need to change time interval between clicks.
    You can set its value from 10 hours to 100 miliseconds.
    Minimal step is 50 miliseconds.
  • There is a possiblity to save your settings. Settings are stored in Windows Registry File.
    Click-Catch(c) has no instalation procedure (it's only one file after all!)
    so it can not delete its entry after deinstalation (delete).
    It has however an option called ""clear WinRegFile entry"".
    Use it freely
column5:
it is harmless.
  • You can check if there is new version available to download easely. Simply chose Help/Check for update!
    • ";"help-http://www.oatsoft.org/Software/click-catch/help

column3: including difficulties to read or write
column4: may use symbols as an alternative or complement to character based texts. Referencing to
column5:
and exchanging these alternatively coded messages over the Internet is difficult due to the lack of standardised encoding schemes and common practises. The Concept Coding Framework (CCF) is being developed to overcome some of these difficulties.";"

News

3 February 2011 - (Mats Lundälv)

In spite of nothing appearing at this spot for quite some time
column7: currently in the context of the AEGIS project. More to appear here soon after the recent move of the server home of OATS
column8:
as well as for the conceptcoding.org domain. More to come - soon hopefully ...


3 September 2009 - (Mats Lundälv)

The summer has passed and the work towards the first CCF release is slowly progressing. Will we make it during the 3rd quarter of 2009 as envisaged ? Well - surprise - possibly not :-/ It currently looks uncertain whether we will be ready during this month. It will probably be a bit later this autumn.

Bengt Farre's completely re-written new SYMBERED version is getting close to completion
column9:
but still has some way to go.

The good news is that Lars Nordberg is well on the way to transfer our CCF databases from MySQL to the Sun JavaDB (based on Apache Derby) Java database. This will provide another option for providing CCF resources (in addition to the MySQL and RDF resources) in a light weight format that will be easier to deploy
column10:
install and use for those who will like to try working with CCF based applications and services.

We'll keep you updated at this space ..


19 June 2009 - (Mats Lundälv)

A first full release of the updated CCF package is now envisaged during the 3rd quarter of 2009. It will cover a set of concepts covering the authorized Blissymbolics vocabulary of around 4450 Bliss-words. These will be organised in a Base Reference Ontology (BRO) with concepts covered by WordNet
column11: and a Complementary Reference Ontology (CRO) for the rest. The Concept Coded concepts in the Reference Ontologies will be linked to an open ended numbers of so called Assistive Ontologies containing the different supported language representations for the concepts - Bliss being the first target for graphical symbol representations
column12: and English and Swedish being the first natural language lexicons fully supported. The structure is already prepared for supporting a number of other symbolic representations
column14:
and a number of other European languages. More will be added as soon as interest and resources will be around.

In technical terms; the first release will contain a Java based CCF Tool for browsing and managing the CCF resources (WordNet
column16:
Assistive Ontologies and symbol resources). The data will be stored in or retrieved from either a MySQL database or an RDF/XML based resource.

The first practical implementation will be an updated version of the SYMBERED tool for creating symbol supported web content via a CMS module written in PHP working towards the MySQL database. (This will be a complete re-write of the first SYMBERED version based on the Papunet CMS). 

The next practical implementation will be the first prototypes of the envisaged CCF symbol support plugin extension for OpenOffice.org within the AEGIS project - planned for the 4th quarter of 2009.

08 June 2009 - (Mats Lundälv)

In the AEGIS project 1:st international workshop (in Slough at RIM 05 June) Dr. Christian Galinski from Infoterm gave a very interesting and informative presentation on issues concerning ""Standards for content in the field of eInclusion - and beyond"" - with great relevance for the CCF work in particular
column17:
and for the AEGIS and Raising The Floor projects in general. We will have to do some studying about ISO//TC 37 ""Terminology and other language and content resources"" ;-)  I hope the presentations will be on-line soon.

22 February 2009 - (Mats Lundälv)

The  concept coding work has continued in slow pace as follow up work after the Nordic SYMBERED project - which is still ongoing.
It is now brought further in relation to a task within the ongoing European and international AEGIS-project. Concept coding will be employed in building open source components for graphic symbol support - in OpenOffice.org
column18:
as well as in prototype Java based cross-platform AAC applications - for mobile devices and other environments.

03/12/2007 - (Andy Judson)

With my move from the University of Dundee's School of Computing
column19: I thought it time I ported the old CCF website to the OATS portal. With the Bliss Think Tank in July'07 we've been busy hacking more demonstrators. Mats
column20: Bengt and Lars have been busy fine-tuning the SYMBERED system (CCF support for CMS - using PHP
column22: Java). I've been busy working on a .NET infrastructure and building a central CCF ontology in SQLServer. The database I've been working with is now populated with around 9000 concepts (based on the STANDUP project ontology) and around 3000 Bliss symbols (some of which are mapped to concept codes). There is an prototype asp.net website where you can search the ontologies
column24: write ruby annotated bliss messages (then you can copy the source to your own website like I've done below). This webservice could be used as a portal to manage the ccf
column26: for use by other software / web applications
column27:
e.g. FoxySymbols. I hope to get the webservice & database hosted soon.

Background

Around the world
column29: including difficulties to read or write
column30: may use symbols as an alternative or complement to character based texts. Referencing to
column31: and exchanging these alternatively coded messages over the Internet is difficult due to the lack of standardised encoding schemes and common practises. This site is intended to motivate
column32: describe and promote the introduction and adoption of a common
column33:
open and vendor neutral Concept Coding Framework (CCF) to overcome some of these difficulties. In particular will act as a base for all contribution to this work - be it formal documentation or informal discussions.

The suggested CCF has been carefully designed to be conformant to the standard language technologies that are rapidly developing and penetrating the Internet communities. In this way we believe that the proposed CCF can contribute to a major leap in bridging between different technologies and products developed for AAC users and
column35:
between these Assistive Technologies (AT) and the main-stream technologies of today's and tomorrow's networked information society.

The bridging approach also implies that the CCF is not intended to replace and exclude the use and development of current and future proprietary assistive technologies in the AAC field. Instead the CCF and its bridging technology and tools are designed to provide added value for all stake-holders; AAC users
column36: special product developers and service providers
column37:
as well as general service and information providers who want to support improved accessibility to their products.

Designed to be used over the Internet for email
column39: chat and/or other emerging Internet based services
column42: be used by software manufacturers also to provide additional functionality
column45:
software and systems with multi-modal language features mainly intended for local use.

Although
column46: this work is part of the EU funded WWAAC project
column47:
the concept coding work is to be kept open source as we want to collaborate with experts and stakeholders in both the AAC field and internet technologies/accessibility area. Thus we are wanting to use this area to establish an interest group in the concept coding approach. if you are interested in getting involved at whatever level then please contact us.

Dasher;"Dasher is an information-efficient text-entry interface
column2:
driven by natural continuous pointing gestures.";"

From the authors:

Dasher is a zooming interface. You point where you want to go
column3: and the display zooms in wherever you point. The world into which you are zooming is painted with letters
column4: so that any point you zoom in on corresponds to a piece of text. The more you zoom in
column5:
the longer the piece of text you have written. You choose what you write by choosing where to zoom.

To make the interface efficient
column6: we use the predictions of a language model to determine how much of the world is devoted to each piece of text. Probable pieces of text are given more space
column7: so they are quick and easy to select. Improbable pieces of text (for example
column8: text with spelling mistakes) are given less space
column9: so they are harder to write. The language model learns all the time: if you use a novel word once
column10:
it is easier to write next time.


A big advantage of Dasher over other predictive text-entry interfaces that offer word-completions to the user is that it is mode-free: the user does not need to switch from a writing mode to an ""accept-model-predictions"" mode.

Another advantage is that it is easy to train the model on any writing style: simply load up an example file
column11:
then write away!


OATS Comment:

Dasher is an amazing innovation on on-screen keyboards - although at first it might seem difficult
column12:
stick with it and you will be astounded at how efficient it is.  Although mainly aimed at users who can use a mouse (or similar device) the Dasher team are working on a switch accessible version.  There is also a version that works well with speech recognition software - Speech Dasher.

See Dasher in action:

David MacKay demonstrated Dasher at the Bett 2006 Special Needs Fringe and you can watch the video created by Leon Cych.Dasher 4.9.0 is now available for download from:

 

  http://download.gnome.org/sources/dasher/4.9/

 

Windows binaries will shortly be available from:

 

 http://www.dasher.org.uk/Download.html

 

Dasher is a predictive text input system for the GNOME Desktop
column13:
suitable for any situation in which a conventional keyboard cannot be used.

 

This is the first in a new development series
column14: including a large number of improvements from a wide variety of contributors. As always
column15: thanks to all Dasher developers and contributors. Please file any bug reports in the GNOME Bugzilla
column16:
and send any comments and feedback to dasher@mrao.cam.ac.uk

";"help-http://www.inference.phy.cam.ac.uk/dasher/DasherSummary2.html

Enable Viacam can be used as a full alternative or as a complement to a conventional computer mouse. It is especially useful for people with motor impairments in their hands or their arms (due to bone injuries

License

From the developer:

eSpeak uses a ""formant synthesis"" method. This allows many languages to be provided in a small size. The speech is clear
column3: and can be used at  high speeds
column4:
but is not as natural or smooth as larger synthesizers which are based on human speech recordings.

eSpeak is available as:

  • A command line program (Linux and Windows) to speak text from a file or from stdin.
  • A shared library version for use by other programs. (On Windows this is a DLL).
  • A SAPI5 version for Windows
column5:
so it can be used with screen-readers and other programs that support the Windows SAPI5 interface.
  • eSpeak has been ported to other platforms
column6:
including Solaris and Mac OSX.

Features.

  • Includes different Voices
column7:
whose characteristics can be altered.
  • Can produce speech output as a WAV file.
  • SSML (Speech Synthesis Markup Language) is supported (not complete)
column8:
and also HTML.
  • Compact size. The program and its data
column10:
totals about 1.4 Mbytes.
  • Can be used as a front-end to MBROLA diphone voices
column11:
see mbrola.html. eSpeak converts text to phonemes with pitch and length information.
  • Can translate text into phoneme codes
column12:
so it could be adapted as a front end for another speech synthesis engine.
  • Potential for other languages. Several are included in varying stages of progress. Help from native speakers for these or other languages is welcome.
  • Development tools are available for producing and tuning phoneme data.

column1: eStoryMaker;"A simple means for assembling text
column2:
picture and sound files into an e-story that supports multiple access means.";"

eStoryMaker is a simple program for assembling an e-story that affords multiple access methods. eStoryMaker can be used to e-book versions of your student's favorite children's books
column3: to recap field trips or special events
column5: or to provide a multimedia accounting of each step in a task. eStoryMaker is also designed to work well with Launcher6. In spite of its name
column6: you construct an e-story by placing text
column7: picture and/or sound files in a folder along with the eStoryMaker.exe file. When you open eStoryMaker.exe
column9: page1.jpg and page1.wav (for example.) When your user asks for the next page
column10: eStoryMaker loads the next set of files in the page sequence
column12: you have to name your picture files
column14: and create text files. You can use a clipboard text-to-speech program to read your story
column15:
if you don't want to bother with recording sound files.

There are many freeware tools you can use to help create e-stories. To make e-books from children's books you can use a flatbed scanner
column16: but I often just use a digital camera for quicker results. I take the books outside and shoot the pages in the shade to have good light
column17: but no glare. For picture editing and renaming I recommend using the excellent and free IrfanView program easily obtained from the Internet. To record sound files I most often use the Sound Recorder accessory that comes with Windows. For more precise sound editing
column18: and for converting wav to mp3 files I use the terrific free Audacity program. There are many better free
column19: Internet available alternatives for creating text files than the default Windows Notepad. I have been using a program called EditPad that most importantly supports multiple files being open simultaneously (unlike Notepad.) Finally
column20: I can recommend 2 freeware text-to-speech programs
column21: Deskbot and SayzMe. Both are easily obtained on the Internet and use the freeware Microsoft Agent technology. I prefer Deskbot
column22: and set its options to read the clipboard text only without any extra

From the author:


Eventcorder allows sequences of keystrokes and mouse-clicks (events) to be recorded
column3: and then played back at the touch of a button. It also allows recorded sequences (known as macros) to be edited. The software matches up events with the window for which they were recorded
column4: and will wait for the correct window to open before implementing a particular event
column5:
so that events cannot act in the wrong window.


";"help-http://www.eventcorder.com/ec_contact.htm

FatBits;"Fatbits magnifies an area of the screen and paints the giant pixels into a new window

you can modify the colours it displays.";"

What the authors say:

FatBits magnifies an area of the screen centered around the mouse pointer and paints the giant pixels into a small
column4: tastefully decorated window. This can be indispensable when you want to see something right down to the last pixel. Once the text has been magnified (up to 20x)
column6:
and change the colours used. The website contains an online User Manual.


OATS Comments:

FatBits was originally designed for graphic artists or people designing user interfaces

but it may be relevant to some people with visual impairments.  This has not yet been tested by the OATS team.

column1: Fire Vox;"Fire Vox is an open source

freely available talking browser extension for the Firefox web browser.";"

Think of it as a screen reader that is designed especially for Firefox.

In addition to the basic features that are expected of screen readers
column3: such as being able to identify headings
column7: Fire Vox provides support for MathML and CSS speech module properties. It also works on Windows
column9:
and Linux.

CLC-4-TTS is a cross OS compatible (Windows
column11:
Linux) collection of JavaScript functions that can be used for transforming Firefox into a self-voicing browser. This software is open source and is licensed under the terms of the GNU GPL.

";"help-http://www.firevox.clcworld.net/developers.html

column1: FireFox;"The award-winning Web browser is better than ever. Browse the Web with confidence - Firefox protects you from viruses
column2: spyware and pop-ups. Enjoy improvements to performance
column3:
ease of use and privacy. It's easy to import your favorites and settings and get started. Download Firefox now and get the most out of the Web.";"

From the authors:

A Better Web Experience

Firefox 2.0.0.1 has an intuitive interface and blocks viruses
column5: and popup ads. It delivers Web pages faster than ever. And it’s easy to install and import your favorites. Packed with useful features like tabbed browsing
column8: Firefox will change the way you experience the Web
column9:
for the better.

Accessibility

Firefox 2.0.0.1 delivers easier navigation for everyone
column10: including those who are visually or motor-impaired. Firefox is the first browser to support DHTML accessibility
column13: allows rich Web applications to be read aloud. Users may navigate with keystrokes rather than mouse clicks
column14:
reducing the tabbing required to navigate documents such as spreadsheets. Firefox 1.5 (Windows version) is also the first browser to meet US federal government requirements that software be easily accessible to users with physical impairments. Full details of Firefox accessibility features.

Faster Browsing

Enjoy quick page loading as you navigate back and forward in a browsing session. Improvements to the engine that powers Firefox deliver more accurate display of complex Web sites
column16:
and better overall performance.

Automatic Updates

The new Software Update feature makes it easy to get the latest security and feature updates to Firefox. Firefox automatically downloads these small updates in the background and prompts you when they are ready to be installed.

Tabbed Browsing

Use tabbed browsing to open multiple Web pages in a single browser window
column17:
and quickly flip back and forth. Drag and drop open tabs to keep related pages together.

Improved Pop-up Blocking

Firefox’s built-in pop-up blocker has been enhanced to block more unwanted pop-up and pop-under ads.

Integrated Search

Tap into the power of the Web’s most popular search engines with the built-in Search bar
column18:
and easily add new engines.

Live Bookmarks

Stay up to date with your favorite Web sites and blogs. Use Live Bookmarks that update themselves automatically with the latest content from the Web.

Customize Firefox

Select new button controls for your toolbars
column19: install extensions to add new features
column20:
or change the look of your browser with themes - the way Firefox looks and works is under your control.

Next Generation Web Support

Innovative new Web applications and services deliver a richer Web experience. Support for open Web standards in Firefox ensures you can get the most out of this emerging class of Web-based tools.

AccessFirefox showcases the accessibility tools and features that are available for Firefox
column21:
and to provide Firefox accessibility information and resources.

Firefox
column22: the popular open source web browser

have improved their use of 'accesskeys' which enable you to browse just using the keyboard.

Game Accessibility Suite;"Code library and utilities to enhance accessibility to existing and future games (Win32).";"

The Game Accessibility Suite [GAS] is a collection of utilities built to make video games more accessible. The current focus is the Win32 platform (esp. Windows XP).  It is released under an MIT-style license.


Currently
column2:
there are a handful of utilities being developed alongside a core library including:

  • GASCap
column3:
a utility for in-game closed-captioning of DirectX-based video games.
  • GASPedal
column4:
an in-game utility for switch control of DirectX games.
  • GASThrottle
column5:
a utility to control the speed of modern games.
Currently
column6:
only GASThrottle is far enough along for a released (functional) prototype.

";"help-http://gameaccess.sourceforge.net/

column1: Game Commander;"Game Commander is a voice recognition program designed for games commands
column2:
but which can be used for general voice commands.";"

What the authors say:

Game Commander is a voice control application for games. Many of today's games have a lot of keyboard commands that can be hard to remember. Game Commander takes you to the next level of gaming by enabling you to control most Windows® 98/Me/2000/XP games with verbal commands instead of or in tandem with keyboard
column5: instead of remembering that Alt+Shift+F8 is the            command for lock missiles
column6:
you can just say ""Lock Missiles.""

OATS Comments:

Most of the versions of this software are commerical
column7: however the free trial listed here is actually quite useful!  It is not time limited
column8:
but limits the number of keystrokes sent per command to one and the number of commands in a list to 5.  This might be OK for some people!

";"";Other function

column1: Gaze Talk;"GazeTalk is a predictive text entry system that has a restricted on-screen keyboard with ambiguous layout for severely disabled people. The main reason for using such a keyboard layout is that it enables the use of an eye tracker with a low spatial resolution (e.g.
column2:
a web-camera based eye tracker).";"

From the Authors:

The goal of the GazeTalk project is to develop an eye-tracking based ACC system that supports several languages
column4: and is both sufficiently feature-complete to be deployed as the primary AAC tool for users
column5: yet sufficiently flexible and technically advanced to be used for research purposes. The system is designed for several target languages
column9:
German and Japanese.

Main features:

  • type-to-talk
  • writing
  • email
  • web – browser
  • Multimedia – player
  • PDF – reader
  • letter and word prediction
column10:
and word completion
  • speech output
  • can be operated by gaze
column14:
or any other pointing device
  • supports step-scanning (new!)
  • supports users with low precision in their movements
column15:
or trackers with low accuracy
  • allows the user to use Dasher inside GazeTalk and to transfer the text written in Dasher back to GazeTalk

    • GazeTalk 5.0 has been designed and developed by the Eye Gaze Interaction Group at the IT University of Copenhagen and the IT-Lab at the Royal School of Library and Information Science
column16:
Copenhagen.


OATS Comment

This may also be a useful predictive communication system for literate people who use a mouse to access the computer (as well as eye-gaze).

";"help-http://www.cogain.org/results/applications/results/applications/gazetalk/Short_manual_for_GazeTalk_5_2%20_2.pdf

column1: Gnopernicus;"The Gnopernicus project aims to enable users with limited vision
column3:
to use the Gnome 2 desktop and Gnome/GTK+-2 applications effectively.";"

from the Authors

By providing automated focus tracking and fullscreen magnification
column5: and its screen reader features allow low-vision and blind users access to standard GTK+2 and Java-based GUI applications via speech and braille output. By leveraging Gnome 2's built-in accessibility framework
column6: Gnopernicus will make interacting with applications more efficient for these users
column7:
and enable use of the Gnome 2 desktop for some users who otherwise would have no access to Gnome.

Gnopernicus is available from GNOME CVS in pre-release form
column8: but is not yet feature complete. Information on how to build

Hark The Sound;"Hark The Sound is a really simple sound game intended for young kids who are visually impaired. It was inspired by my friend and colleague Diane Brauner and was written by Gary Bishop. It is free for educational and fun use.";"

From the author:


What is it like?

The object of the game is to name a sound or tune that is presented as a prompt. A typical round in Name That Animal goes like this:

  1. You hear ""Can you name this animal?""
  2. Then an animal sound is played
column2:
for example a dog barking.
  • You use the left or right arrow keys on the keyboard to move through and hear the possible answers. In this case they might be ""Cat""
column6:
the down arrow key will give a hint about the correct answer.
  • When you hear the correct answer
column7:
you press the up arrow key to guess.
  • If the chosen answer is correct
column8: you will hear a reward sound which might be a crowd cheering
column9: or a musical fan fare. If the answer is incorrect
column10:
you will hear ""Try again."".
  • The process then repeats playing another one of the sounds for the four animals.
  • When all the animals in the group have been played
column11:
the game begins another round with four more animals.

When Hark The Sound first starts it says ""Use the left or right arrow keys to choose a game to play."" Using the arrow keys you can move through and hear the choices for games (listed below). When you hear a game you want to play
column12:
use the up arrow key to select it.

The Escape key (often labeled ESC in the upper left corner of the keyboard) will quit the current game and return to the game selections.

What games are available?

All the games follow the same general pattern as described above of Question
column15:
Reward. Games that ship with version 1.2 of Hark The Sound include:

  • Braille Letters: The question is ""Can you name this Braille letter?"". The prompts are the dots of a letter. The answers are the letter along with a word that begins with that letter to make it easier to hear.
  • Braille Whole Word Contractions: The question is ""Can you name this Braille whole word contraction?"" The prompts are the dots in a Braille letter that is a whole word contraction. The word is the answer.
  • Counting: Counting repeated animal sounds for numbers one through nine.
  • Multiplication drills: The full multiplication table up to 12 times 12. The question is ""What is this product?"". The prompts are products like ""2 times 3"" and the answers are numbers from 0 through 144.
  • Name That Animal: Animal sounds are the prompts. The animal's names are the answers.
  • Name that capital's State: A challenging game of State Capitals. The question is ""Can you name the state whose capital is...""
column16:
the prompts are the names of capital cities. The answers are the names of the 50 states.
  • Name that Classical Tune: Midi versions of famous classical music are the prompts. The composer's name and the name of the work are included in the answer.
  • Name that color: The question is ""What color is this?""
column18:
and the answers are their colors.
  • Name That Country Music Tune: Country music classics rendered in Midi. Composer and name are the answer.
  • Name that holiday: Identify holidays from hints.
  • Name that Kids Tune: Midi tunes like ""Head Shoulders Knees and Toes"".
  • Name that Rock and Roll Tune: Classic rock and roll tunes rendered in Midi with the artist and title for the answer.
  • Name that Sound: Environmental sounds
column19:
such as ""clock ticking"" and ""glass breaking"" are the prompts
  • Spelling Words: The prompt is a word spelled out. The answer is the word pronounced.
  • State Nick Names: A challenging game to identify the nick name for a state given its name.


    • ";"help-http://www.oatsoft.org/Software/hark-the-sound/help

ICUTalk;"ICUTalk was a research project
column2: funded by the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council (EPSRC) from 1999 to 2002. The project developed an Augmentative and Alternative Communication (AAC) system to help patients in Intensive Care Units (ICU) who are temporarily unable to speak due to their medical condition or treatment
column3: namely the intubation procedure. This was a multi-disciplinary collaborative project involving staff from the University of Dundee (School of Computing and the School of Nursing & Midwifery)  and Ninewells Hospital
column4: Dundee (Speech & Language Therapy and Intensive Care Unit). Andy Judson was the software developer and Professor Ian Ricketts was the principal investigator.";;"contact_address-mailto:andy.judson@gmail.com";Alternative and Augmentative Communication

column1: AAC Keys;"AAC Keys is a keyboard and mouse emulation program for Microsoft Windows-based and Macintosh computers. AAC Keys receives commands through your computer's serial port and translates them into keystrokes and mouse movements
column2: giving you full control of your computer from another device such as an AAC system. (If your computer has only USB ports

an inexpensive adapter is available.)";"

From the authors:


AAC Keys is a keyboard and mouse emulation program for Microsoft Windows-based and Macintosh computers.

AAC Keys receives commands through your computer's serial port and translates them into keystrokes and mouse moves
column4:
giving you full control of your computer from another device. AAC Keys implements the common GIDEI (General Input Device Emulating Interface) commands (see below).

AAC Keys has been designed to work with Windows 95
column8:
and Windows 2000 operating systems.

A Macintosh version was developed following the introduction of OS X . (Earlier Macintosh operating systems included SerialKeys.) The Macintosh version was developed by computer science students at Millersville University of Pennsylvania under the supervision of Dr. Blaise Liffick.

";"help-http://www.aacinstitute.org/Resources/ProductsandServices/AACKeys/AACKeysHelp.html

Accerciser is also the first GNOME module

column1: Accessible BBC Listen Again;"The British Broadcast Company (BBC) allows people to listen to vast quantities of their radio output up to a week after it is first broadcast on one of their dozens of radio stations. This service
column3: relies on a web browser interface that might be difficult for some users
column4:
especially people with screen readers. Accessible BBC Listen Again allows you to access the BBC's Listen Again content through a truly accessible interface designed to work with any screen reader.";"

From the authors:


Select programmes and stations with the cursor keys and listen to them at your leisure. You get easy and simple access to hours of programming
column5:
including the ever-popular ""The Archers"" and ""In Touch"".

The new version (2.1) lets you access all of the Listen Again content among many other improvements (thanks to everyone for their suggestions!) It does still require that you have already installed RealPlayer from Real. The copyright of the BBC recordings is unchanged: you are simply accessing them through a more accessible presentation of their own website. Version 2.1 should work better on more machines: several users contacted me with problems with 2.0

You are likely to find that some feeds don't work: this may be because the feed is not valid. You can check the feed's validity at the Feed Validator service.

column1: Accessible BBC Listen Again;"The British Broadcast Company (BBC) allows people to listen to vast quantities of their radio output up to a week after it is first broadcast on one of their dozens of radio stations. This service
column3: relies on a web browser interface that might be difficult for some users
column4:
especially people with screen readers. Accessible BBC Listen Again allows you to access the BBC's Listen Again content through a truly accessible interface designed to work with any screen reader.";"

From the authors:


Select programmes and stations with the cursor keys and listen to them at your leisure. You get easy and simple access to hours of programming
column5:
including the ever-popular ""The Archers"" and ""In Touch"".

The new version (2.1) lets you access all of the Listen Again content among many other improvements (thanks to everyone for their suggestions!) It does still require that you have already installed RealPlayer from Real. The copyright of the BBC recordings is unchanged: you are simply accessing them through a more accessible presentation of their own website. Version 2.1 should work better on more machines: several users contacted me with problems with 2.0

From the authors:

Accessible RSS is an accessible application that lets you access these RSS feeds. It displays the headlines from web pages that support RSS. At present four sites (the BBC
column5: the Guardian and the Daily Telegraph) are supported
column6: but you can add  your own if you find a site with an RSS feed. If you have WebbIE you can  press return on a story to launch WebbIE with that story page

but you do not need WebbIE to read the feeds. If you do not have WebbIE the story will be shown in Internet Explorer

  • WebbIE 3 Installer - includes the latest Accessible RSS News Reader.

You are likely to find that some feeds don't work: this may be because the feed is not valid. You can check the feed's validity at the Feed Validator service.

ACollab;"ACollab is an accessible
column4: Web-based collaborative work environment. Group member
column6: and system administrator tools are all compliant with international accessibility standards (WCAG 1.0

Section 508 US) so people with disabilities can participate fully in collaborative and administrative activities.";"

ACollab is available as a work groups addon for ATutor 1.4+
column8: and as a standalone collaborative work environment that will run on its own. ACollab is ideal for groups working at a distance developing documentation
column11: and ideal for online educators who wish to add group learning activities to their ATutor courses. A demo and download are available if you want to learn more. Or
column12:
read on for a list of ACollab features.

ACollab Features:

  • Document Drafting Room: Group members can work within a Web-based document versioning system
column13:
collaborating on document development and publication. Documents developed in the Drafting Room can be transferred to the Shared Documents Library once finalized.
  • Shared Documents Library: Group members can submit documents to the library
column16:
can retrieve those documents for viewing or downloading.
  • Events Calendar: Events can be posted to the calendar by all group members
column20:
or other group related happenings.
  • News & Announcements: Group administrators
column22:
can post news to be presented to users when they first login to a group.
  • Group Membership Index: Group members can view other group members' profiles and contact information.
  • Mail Inbox: Members can communicate with each other privately.
  • AChat-PHP: Accessible synchronous communication is possible between group members
column23:
ideal for online meetings or group socializing.
  • AForum: AForum is an enhanced version for the ATutor forums. Members post message for others to retrieve later. Forums can be set to read only
column24: reply only
column26:
or can be hidden from view.
  • Multi-Lingual Interface: Language can be modified by system administrators
column27:
or new language packs can be created using the ATutor.ca translation tools.
  • Accessibility Compliance: Group member
column29: and system administrator tools are all compliant with international accessibility standards (WCAG 1.0
column30:
Section 508 US) so people with disabilities can participate fully in collaborative and administrative activities.
  • Group Leaders: Create chat transcripts
column36:
and manage group members.
  • System Administrator: Create and manage groups
column37: manage the system languages
column38:
and manage all users on a system.

Acomm;"AComm is an accessible Java-based Instant Messaging and Whiteboard tool. It has been designed to allow assistive technology users to participate in synchronous Internet-based communication activities that have traditionally been inaccessible to them.";"


AComm Features

  • User can login to an existing Jabber account or sign up for a new one.
  • Roster provides ""presence"" information for contacts.
  • Users can participate in private or group chat/whiteboard sessions
  • Text chat window and optional whiteboard
  • Participant list on demand.
  • A variety of whiteboard drawing tools are available
  • Peer description allows any participant to describe the drawn objects. Anti-collision feature ensures one describer per object.
  • Accessibility options
    • Option to play sound effect when a new message arrives.
    • Keyboard drawing checkbox
    • Manual refresh checkbox
    • Show only new checkbox
    • Newest message first checkbox
  • Keyboard enabled drawing lets users use some features of the whiteboard without a mouse.
  • Save and open palette feature lets users create and describe pictures beforehand.

Requirements

  • AComm is a Java application and requires that a Java Runtime Environment be installed on system it is running on.

";"help-http://www.oatsoft.org/Software/acomm/help

column1: Agrip;"The of this project aim is to provide access to the mainstream gaming community not by producing specialist ""accessible games"" but by making mainstream games - and their associated extension and development tools - accessible. Downloads include an accessible version of Quake
column2:
the popular PC game.";"

From the Authors:


Over the past two years
column3: AGRIP has developed an accessible version of Quake and QuakeWorld which allows both single and multi-player games
column4: including the collection of online player statistics. In the future we will add immersive 3D audio and level editing facilities - in addition to the gameplay modifications that are currently possible. At each milestone in the project
column5:
we make public releases of our software.

This page explains the history of the project and the technology involved in more detail.

Contents:

  1. About the AGRIP Project
  2. About our Games
  3. The Technology we Use

About the AGRIP Project

Accessible Gaming Rendering Independence Possible (you can see why we shorten it to ""AGRIP""!) was started in May 2003 with the goal of making a mainstream first-person shooter game for the sighted accessible. It was founded by MatthewAtkinson and SabahattinGucukoglu. This section provides all sorts of information about the project. It is split into the following sections:

  • /ProjectRationale - all about what we're doing and why we're doing it.

  • /TheRoadmap - our plans for development - posted here so you can contact us with suggestions on how to improve them.

  • /TheLogo - description and explanation of the logo
column6:
plus an audio version of it.

  • /OnlineShop - information on how to show your support for the project
column7:
by wearing an AGRIP T-Shirt.

If you've got any suggestions for further topics that could be added to this page (or others)
column8:
feel free to either add them in yourself or ContactUs with your suggestions.

About our Games

For more information about the software on offer here
column9:
you can visit the start pages for each game:

  • AccessibleQuake - the original mainstream game made accessible

  • AudioQuake - the next generation Internet AudioGame

The Technology we Use

The world of game technology is a very interesting one. Here are links to some pages on the Wiki that you can use to start exploring and learning about the various bits and pieces fit together:

  • GameStructure

  • GameEngine

  • GameCode

  • QuakeC

  • AudioGame

  • ImplicitAccessibility


";"help-http://www.agrip.org.uk/DevelopmentSection

column1:
Amaya;"Amaya is a complete Open Source accessible web browsing and authoring environment from WC3";"


W3C's Editor/Browser

Amaya is a Web editor
column2:
i.e. a tool used to create and update documents directly on the Web. Browsing features are seamlessly integrated with the editing and remote access features in a uniform environment. This follows the original vision of the Web as a space for collaboration and not just a one-way publishing medium.

Work on Amaya started at W3C in 1996 to showcase Web technologies in a fully-featured Web client. The main motivation for developing Amaya was to provide a framework that can integrate as many W3C technologies as possible. It is used to demonstrate these technologies in action while taking advantage of their combination in a single
column3:
consistent environment.

Amaya started as an HTML + CSS style sheets editor. Since that time it was extended to support XML and an increasing number of XML applications such as the XHTML family
column5:
and SVG. It allows all those vocabularies to be edited simultaneously in compound documents.

Amaya includes a collaborative annotation application based on Resource Description Framework (RDF)
column7:
and XPointer. Visit the Annotea project home page.

Amaya - Open Source

Amaya is an open source software project hosted by W3C. You are invited to contribute in many forms (documentation
column11:
porting to other platforms...).

The Amaya software is written in C and is available for Windows
column12:
Unix platforms and MacOS X.

Amaya Team

The application is jointly developed by W3C and the WAM (Web
column13: Adaptation and Multimedia) project at INRIA. The core team includes: Irène Vatton (Project lead
column20: Accessing the Web
